tool.name: UpdateWROClassification

param.name: inMosaic
param.dialogReference: Input weighted overlay mosaic. Use the Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic tool to create a new mosaic before running this tool.
param.pythonReference: Input weighted overlay mosaic. Use the Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic tool to create a new mosaic before running this tool.

param.name: in_mosaic_row
param.dialogReference: The layer in the mosaic that you want to change. Choose the layer from the dropdown. All parameters below this dropdown will populate with the data specific to this layer. You cannot change this parameter.
param.pythonReference: The layer in the mosaic that you want to change

param.name: wroTitle
param.dialogReference: The title of the layer that will appear in the Suitability modeler widget in GeoPlanner or Web AppBuilder.
param.pythonReference: The title of the layer that will appear in the Suitability modeler widget in GeoPlanner or Web AppBuilder.

param.name: mosaicLayerData
param.expression: Range Label {Min Range} {Max Range} {Suitability Value};Range Label {Min Range} {Max Range} {Suitability Value}...
param.dialogReference:
The collection of ranges that make up a layer in the mosaic. These ranges are read by the Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic Tool from classify or unique value renderers configured on layers in your map. If a layer was configured with a stretch renderer, Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic creates an equal interval classification.

You will most likely want to change range labels and suitability values. Change labels to a short phrase that describes the meaning of a class (a range). For example: Very Low; Very Far; High Risk; Probably Exists. Change suitability values to reflect a range's impact within the analysis. For example, range value 75-100 represents the highest density of a phenomena within a layer. Set this range's suitability value to 9 to indicate highest risk or opportunity.

Ranges represent a class of data values in a layer. For example, a layer with values from 1-100 could have 4 classes: 1-25; 25-50; 50-75;75-100. Ranges are read from layers and written into the mosaic with the Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic tool. Ranges have 4 elements: Label; Min Range; Max Range; and Suitability Value.

  1. Range Label - The label for a classification in the Suitability widget.

  2. Min Range - The classification's minimum value. For a class of values from 1-25, the min range value would be 1.

  3. Max Range - The classification's maximum value. For a class of values from 1-25, the max range value would be 25. NOTE: Classifications are max-exclusive, meaning a range of 1-25 would include all values between 1 to 25 but not 25.

  4. Suitability Value - The suitability value for the range defined in Min Range to Max Range. Ranges are remapped to this suitability value. For example, for a class of values 1-25, all values between 1-25, but not including 25, are remapped to the suitability value you choose from this dropdown. You can only choose values 0-9. By default, all suitability values are set to 5.

NOTE: Ranges must include all dataset values. For example, if you have a raster dataset with values from 1-100, you must define ranges that include all of these values. The tool will return an error if it detects missing values.

NOTE: Each min range value should equal the previous range's max value. For example, given 4 classes of 1-25, 25-50, 50-75, 75-100, your Min Range and Max Range values would be:

  • Min Range = 1

  • Max Range = 25

  • Min Range = 25

  • Max Range = 50

  • Min Range = 50

  • Max Range = 75

  • Min Range = 75

  • Max Range = 101

The final value is 101 as Max Ranges are exclusive, meaning include all values between 75 and 101 but not 101.
param.pythonReference:
The collection of ranges that make up a layer in the mosaic. These ranges are read by the Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic Tool from classify or unique value renderers configured on layers in your map. If a layer was configured with a stretch renderer, Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic creates an equal interval classification.

You will most likely want to change range labels and suitability values. Change labels to a short phrase that describes the meaning of a class (a range). For example: Very Low; Very Far; High Risk; Probably Exists. Change suitability values to reflect a range's impact within the analysis. For example, range value 75-100 represents the highest density of a phenomena within a layer. Set this range's suitability value to 9 to indicate highest risk or opportunity.

Ranges represent a class of data values in a layer. For example, a layer with values from 1-100 could have 4 classes: 1-25; 25-50; 50-75;75-100. Ranges are read from layers and written into the mosaic with the Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic tool. Ranges have 4 elements: Label; Min Range; Max Range; and Suitability Value.

  1. Range Label - The label for a classification in the Suitability widget.

  4. Suitability Value - The suitability value for the range defined in Min Range to Max Range. Ranges are remapped to this suitability value. For example, for a class of values 1-25, all values between 1-25, but not including 25, are remapped to the suitability value you choose from this dropdown. You can only choose values 0-9. By default, all suitability values are set to 5.

NOTE: Ranges must include all dataset values. For example, if you have a raster dataset with values from 1-100, you must define ranges that include all of these values. The tool will return an error if it detects missing values.

  • Min Range = 1

  • Max Range = 25

  • Min Range = 25

  • Max Range = 50

  • Min Range = 50

  • Max Range = 75

  • Min Range = 75

  • Max Range = 101

The final value is 101 as Max Ranges are exclusive, meaning include all values between 75 and 101 but not 101.

tool.summary: Updates the title and classification ranges of a layer in a weighted overlay mosaic. This tool allows you to refine the classifications created by the Create Weighted Overlay Mosaic tool.
